meta.content: Front Page; New York and Region
meta.name: online_sections

block.p: Sinn Fein Endorses Plan For Ulster Police Reforms Sinn Fein, the main Catholic republican party, voted to endorse the police force in Northern Ireland, opening the way toward restoring local government shared by Protestants and Catholics.
PAGE A4
Saudi Proposes Peace Talks King Abdullah of Saudi Arabia invited the main Palestinian factions Hamas and Fatah to hold talks in Mecca in an effort to halt some of their worst internal fighting.
PAGE A3
Truth and Consequences A federal court is trying to decide when is it all right to punish people for telling the truth about matters of public concern. ''Sidebar'' by Adam Liptak.
PAGE A12
New Push in Fighting Gangs A surge of gang violence brought renewed promises from Los Angeles officials to reverse it and new teams of officers to fight it.
PAGE A16
Behind the 'Dreamgirls' Snub Hollywood executives wonder if excessive marketing could have cost a film an Oscar nomination for best picture.
BUSINESS DAY, PAGE C1
All Noir, All the Time In San Francisco, the fifth Noir City festival, with movies like ''Raw Deal,'' is tapping a renewed interest in film noir.
THE ARTS, PAGE E1

The Prince at the Court Prince Charles, visiting New York with his wife, Camilla, ponders a shot at the Harlem Children's Zone, where he made it on the second try. From there it was on to the Harvard Club for an environmental award.
PAGE B1

Sinn Fein Endorses Plan For Ulster Police Reforms Sinn Fein, the main Catholic republican party, voted to endorse the police force in Northern Ireland, opening the way toward restoring local government shared by Protestants and Catholics.
PAGE A4
